lines.text: Well, she needn't have dropped the platter and insulted my friend. What was it she said to you?
I remember very well, sir. It was, if I may take the liberty of repeating it, 'Nuts to the squirrels.'
Doesn't make sense!

No, it doesn't. It should be 'Squirrels to the nuts.' But I have an open mind, and if someone says to me 'Nuts to the squirrels,' I accept it. You may be inclined to say that to me yourself some day, when you know me better - and I'm not so sure that you will include the 'squirrels.'

[shaking his head]
That's much too deep for me.
In Hyde Park, some people like to feed nuts to the squirrels. But if it makes you happy to feed squirrels to the nuts, who am I to say nuts to the squirrels?
So many of these foreigners have foreign names.
You couldn't have prescribed a better sedative than yourself!
Thank you Sir.
Not at all.
Why do people go to cocktail parties?
Because people give cocktail parties.
Why do people give them?
Because people go to them.
It's a vicious circle... like perpetual motion.
It's depressing. Parties and people laughing with Europe on the brink.
Yes, Hitler and Vienna and Prague and people go around having fun.
Oh, I'm so tired of hearing about Hitler and Mussolini and...
Betty, I'm surprised! You talk like a superficial girl who thinks of nothing but her pink and white complexion.
You seemed to like it until Hitler came between us.
I... I still do.
Oh, intensely, Betty.
But you must realize we're on the verge of a war.
Well then, stop talking and do something about it.
I have. I've written a letter to the Times.
Then there's nothing to worry about.
Relieve the drain, relieve the strain.
You must never become a victim of my circumstances, and, if you should ever seem romantic to me - don't hesitate. Just kick me.
Yes, let's kick each other.

I would build you the most beautiful mansion, with the most exquisite and complicated plumbing, I would hand you a hammer, and say "Ladies and Gentlemen, Madame Cluny Belinski is about to put the pipes in their place".

[hearing news of the war]
I intend to write another letter to the Times.
Good.

[uncertainly]
No... No, I'll join the R.A.F.
Better... join the R.A.F, and rise above the Times.
But I know Hitler.
He has written a book, hasn't he?
Yes.
Big success?
Very big.
So what more does he want? Why doesn't he lie down and keep quiet?
If you really want to know, Sir Henry, read the book.
It's an outdoor book. What is it called? Oh yes, "Mein Camp".

It may interest you to know that after the use of my nasal bath the Marquis Rockamere, a distinguished speaker, was for the first time clearly understood when he addressed the House of Lords last week.
You see she is not dressed for plumbing... but what woman is ?
